Icon is now found in mipmap directory, not drawable

>  It’s best practice to place your app icons in mipmap- folders (not
>  the drawable- folders) because they are used at resolutions different
>  from the device’s current density. For example, an xxxhdpi app icon
>  can be used on the launcher for an xxhdpi device.

Source: https://android-developers.googleblog.com/2014/10/getting-your-apps-ready-for-nexus-6-and.html

title: Merge pull request #22 from rabid/bugfix/compareto-removing-non-unique-entries

Merge pull request #22 from rabid/bugfix/compareto-removing-non-unique-entries

Match for equality on image, not gloss.

title: Match for equality on image, not gloss.
message:
Match for equality on image, not gloss.

The same gloss can be repeated while being unique (for example, 'Auckland' has several variations. I
think the image path is the best attribute to match on. Note that this
may break alphabetic sorting within results, but I don't think this is
vitally important.

title: Use LinkedHashSet for collecting results
message:
Use LinkedHashSet for collecting results

Apparently Java is all about picking the right kind of collection. I'm
definitely not being very considerate of system resources here, but it
does work.

We were using an ArrayList to collate results, which does not enforce
any uniqueness. For search results that had signs that matched in more
than one way (e.g. equals, starts with), the sign would show up twice.
To fix this, I've moved to collating results to a LinkedHashSet, which
enforces uniqueness (first in wins). I experimented with passing the set
back to the activity, but this did not work as the Set interface does
not expose a method to get an item by index, and both the activity and
underlying tests use this method.

title: Request new permission: Access Network State
message:
Request new permission: Access Network State

This permission is required to detect whether the device the app is
running on has a network connection or not. If no network connection is
present, we do not try and load the video, and instead display a message
to the user.

Without this functionality, the videoview times out after a long time -
30 seconds to a minute, during which the videoview displays an empty
black screen.

This is always what we want, and it has the bonus of showing the whole
app when it first opens.

Without this, the keyboard starts visible, taking up up to half of the
app screen. This is pretty bad when the app opens, AND when returning
from a search result (since the search has already been performed)

title: Add new search type for "startsWith" - without this, search results are hopelessly incorret
message:
Add new search type for "startsWith" - without this, search results are hopelessly incorret

Most key words have more than one word in the gloss - for example, "bus, truck"
This prevents an exact match, falling back to a contains match which is wildly wrong.

Instead, we do a starts with match so that at least the primary word matches before
contains matches

title: Populate several arraylists with search results for each search type, and then…
message: Populate several arraylists with search results for each search type, and then concatenate them to get search results in correct order

title: Stop using TreeMap
message:
Stop using TreeMap

TreeMap is not the data structure we want, as it sorts by key, and keys must be unique.
We are wanting to order by weighting, so using this as they key, which results in a maximum
set capacity of _n_, where _n_ is the number of unique weightings we have.

Instead, we must take a more simple approach.

title: Updates to searching to weight results based on the type of match
message:
Updates to searching to weight results based on the type of match

Search weighting is very nearly at the point where a database is
necessary. Micky from NZSL has been notified of this, but we can scrape
by with string matching for now.

The search previously did a contains match on main, secondary and Maori
gloss. This results in many inaccurate matches. The search now follows
the below rules:

* Exact matches on main or maori gloss are preferred and shown as first
  preference
* Inexact matches on main or maori gloss are shown as second preference
* Exact matches on secondary gloss are shown as third preference
* Inexact matches on secondary gloss are shown as fourth preference

This change improves search results, but still yields some strange
results with words matching when we would not expect, or vice-versa. I
expect further changes will be made based on exact search scenarios.
